content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun clash and just the right level of difficulty!

Add multiple numbers, not just three.
Would it be difficult to add multiple numbers?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I see no problems. Very good.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think you can add golf mode.
Don't forget to add a line before "Operations" in @Goal as asked previously.

Good idea for this clash !

Title / Goal / Input / Output
* Consider changing "stack A" to "a stack".

Goal
* Please change "Sorted" to "sorted".

* Please format "sa", "ra", "rra" and "sorted" as {{constants}}. (See formatting syntax here: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement#guidelines .)

* Consider adding a simple example for each of "sa", "ra" and "rra" to make their behaviour easier to understand.

* Please explain how to choose between multiple valid instruction sequences when alternatives exist.

  Example 1: For input 2 1 3, all of the following are valid:
  • sa
  • rra + sa + rra
  • ra + sa + ra
  • ra + rra + sa

  Example 2: For input 1 3 2, the following are valid:
  • sa + ra
  • rra + sa

Input
* Please delete the example and rewrite as:

<<Line 1>>: Three space-separated integers, [[a]], [[b]] and [[c]], representing the elements of a stack.

Output
* Please change "Output the" to "<<One or more lines>>: The".

* Please format "sorted" as a {{constant}}.

Constraints
* Please rewrite the first constraint as:
[[a]], [[b]] and [[c]] are all distinct.

* Please delete the last three constraints, as they're part of the task or output requirement, rather than constraints on case possibilities.

* Please add:
0 ≤ [[a]], [[b]], [[c]] ≤ 10000

Cases
* Each test and its validator should cover the *same* scenario with slightly different inputs. Please revise the cases accordingly.

  For example, the first test and the first validator use "sa" only, and the second pair uses "ra" only, and so on.
  
* Also, the magnitudes of [[a]], [[b]] and [[c]] within each test/validator pair should be similar.

* Please use a more diverse set of values across the full allowed range of 0 to 10000 when constructing inputs.

Thanks.

Thanks a lot for the detailed feedback! I applied all your suggestions, and I also updated the constraints and cases as recommended. Whenever you have a moment, could you please check the new version and let me know what you think?

No, adding more numbers is not difficult, but it changes the nature of the challenge.

In quick games like Clash of Code, the goal is to keep the problem simple, fast to understand, and fast to implement.

Thank you for following up. The contribution looks better now. Just a few more adjustments:

Goal
* Please format "sorted" and "multiple minimal solutions exist" as {{constants}}.

Cases
* Please reduce the frequency of using 1, 2, 3 as stack elements by revising the following tests, so that players understand other numbers can appear:

  • AlreadySorted (Test 2)
  
  • SwapAndReverseRotate (Test 6)

* The answer to SwapAndReverseRotate (Test 6 and Validator 6) should be "multiple minimal solutions exist", because sa + rra and ra + sa are both valid shortest solutions.

Output
* Please change "One or more lines" to "Line 1", since the output will never contain more than one line.

Thanks again.

You're very welcome! Thanks again for taking the time to review and provide such detailed feedback. I've made all the adjustments you suggested.
Looking forward to hearing your thoughts on the updates. Thanks for all your guidance!

You're welcome!

Other than adding a blank line before the heading "Operations" in the Goal section to make the statement easier to read, I don't have further comments for now.
